results.queryText: What form of government does Boise have?
results.responseText:
Boise uses a mayor‚Äìcouncil form of government.

Here‚Äôs what that means in practice for Boise:

üèõÔ∏è How Boise‚Äôs Government Is Structured
üë©‚Äçüíº Mayor (Executive Branch)

The mayor is the city‚Äôs chief executive.

Elected citywide.

Responsibilities include:

Proposing the city budget

Appointing department directors

Enforcing city laws and ordinances

Representing Boise externally

üßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è City Council (Legislative Branch)

The Boise City Council has six members, each elected from a district.

Responsibilities include:

Passing ordinances and resolutions

Approving the budget

Setting city policy

Confirming certain mayoral appointments

The mayor presides over meetings but votes only to break ties.

üßæ Key Characteristics

Strong mayor system (more executive authority than a council-manager model)

Separation of powers between executive (mayor) and legislative (council)

Council members represent specific geographic districts, not the city at large

üìå In contrast to other models

Boise does not use a city manager or commission system.

Day-to-day administration flows through departments overseen by the mayor.

Bottom line

Boise operates under a mayor‚Äìcouncil government, where:

The mayor runs the city

The council makes laws and sets policy

Voters elect both directly

results.queryText: How does Boise's mayor-council government work?
results.responseText:
Here‚Äôs a clear, plain-English breakdown of how Boise‚Äôs mayor‚Äìcouncil government works and who does what.

üèõÔ∏è The Basics

Boise operates under a mayor‚Äìcouncil form of government, sometimes called a strong-mayor system. Power is split between an elected executive (the mayor) and an elected legislative body (the city council).

üë©‚Äçüíº The Mayor (Executive Branch)

The mayor is the city‚Äôs chief executive and runs day-to-day operations.

What the mayor does:

Proposes the annual city budget

Appoints department directors (police, fire, public works, parks, etc.)

Enforces city laws and ordinances

Represents Boise publicly and in intergovernmental matters

Presides over City Council meetings

Votes only to break a tie on the council

Key point: The mayor manages the city‚Äôs administration and sets priorities‚Äîbut doesn‚Äôt make laws alone.

üßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è City Council (Legislative Branch)

Boise‚Äôs City Council has six members, each elected from a geographic district.

What the council does:

Passes ordinances (local laws) and resolutions

Approves or amends the city budget

Sets citywide policy

Confirms certain mayoral appointments

Holds public hearings and takes public comment

Provides oversight of city operations

Council members do not manage departments; they legislate and oversee.

‚öñÔ∏è How Power Is Balanced

Think of it like this:

Role	Primary Power
Mayor	Executive leadership & administration
City Council	Laws, policy, budget approval
Mayor + Council	Budget adoption & major decisions

The mayor proposes, the council disposes (approves, modifies, or rejects).

Neither branch can fully act alone on major decisions.

This creates checks and balances at the city level.

üó≥Ô∏è Elections & Accountability

Mayor: Elected citywide

Council members: Elected by district

Elections are nonpartisan

Terms are staggered so not all seats turn over at once

Voters directly choose both the executive and the legislators.

üß† What This Means for Residents

Want to change policy or laws? ‚Üí Contact your council member

Concerned about how a department operates? ‚Üí Mayor‚Äôs office or council oversight

Speaking at meetings matters‚Äîpublic comment is part of the process

Big decisions (housing, budgets, zoning changes) usually require both branches

üìå In one sentence

Boise‚Äôs mayor‚Äìcouncil system means the mayor runs the city, the council makes the laws, and major decisions require collaboration between the two‚Äîwith voters holding both accountable.

If you want, I can also explain:

How a bill becomes a city ordinance

How the budget moves from proposal to adoption

How residents can influence decisions at each stage

results.queryText: How do I run for Boise City Council?
results.responseText:
Here‚Äôs a clear, step-by-step guide to running for Boise City Council, from eligibility to getting on the ballot and campaigning.

üó≥Ô∏è Overview

Boise City Council has six district-based seats. Members serve four-year terms, with three seats up in each odd-numbered year (e.g., 2025, 2027).

Elections are nonpartisan.

‚úÖ Step 1: Make Sure You‚Äôre Eligible

To run for Boise City Council, you must:

Be at least 18 years old

Be a U.S. citizen

Be a registered voter

Live in the council district you‚Äôre running to represent

Maintain residency in that district during your term

(Residency is district-specific, not citywide.)

üó∫Ô∏è Step 2: Confirm Your Council District

Council seats are elected by district.

Use the City‚Äôs district map to confirm which district you live in.

You may only run in the district where you reside.

If you want, tell me your address and I can help you identify your district.

üßæ Step 3: File as a Candidate

You officially become a candidate by filing with the Ada County Elections Office.

What you file

Declaration of Candidacy

Statement of Residence

Any required affidavits

When to file

Filing typically opens in late August and closes in early September

This is a hard deadline‚Äîno late filings

üìç Filing is done through Ada County Elections, not City Hall.

üí∞ Step 4: Register Campaign Finance

If you raise or spend money:

File a Campaign Finance Registration with the Idaho Secretary of State

Report contributions and expenditures on required schedules

Even small campaigns must comply once money is involved

Many first-time candidates trip up here‚Äîgetting this right early matters.

üó£Ô∏è Step 5: Campaign

Boise council races are grassroots by nature.

Common campaign activities:

Door-to-door canvassing in your district

Neighborhood meetings and forums

Yard signs and mailers

Social media and a simple website

Attending community events and council meetings

Because districts are compact, personal contact matters more than big money.

üóìÔ∏è Step 6: Election Day

Elections are held in November of odd-numbered years

You must receive a plurality of votes (no primary/runoff in most cases)

Winners are sworn in shortly after certification

üß† Practical Tips (Local Reality)

Talk to current or former council members early‚Äîmost are willing to share advice.

Expect the role to be part-time but demanding (evenings, meetings, constituent work).

Learn key city issues early: housing, zoning, transportation, public safety, budget.

Public records, ethics rules, and open meeting laws apply to council members.

üìå Quick Checklist

‚úî Confirm district
‚úî Register to vote
‚úî File candidacy with Ada County (on time)
‚úî Register campaign finance account
‚úî Start voter outreach

If you want, I can help you:

Check exact filing dates for the next election

Build a first-time candidate timeline

results.queryText: What are the biggest challenges facing Boise?
results.responseText:
Here are the biggest challenges facing Boise today, as most residents, planners, and local leaders see them. None are unique to Boise‚Äîbut the city‚Äôs fast growth makes them sharper.

üèôÔ∏è Growth & Housing Affordability

Boise grew very quickly over the past decade, and housing supply hasn‚Äôt kept pace.

What this looks like:

Rising home prices and rents

Fewer options for middle-income families, service workers, and young adults

Pressure on longtime residents who feel priced out

Why it‚Äôs hard:
Boise wants to add housing without losing neighborhood character‚Äîa tough balance that drives frequent zoning and development debates.

üöó Transportation & Infrastructure

Boise remains a car-centric city, and growth has strained systems that were designed for a smaller population.

Key issues:

Increasing traffic congestion

Limited public transit coverage and frequency

Roads and utilities playing catch-up in fast-growing areas

Complication:
Many major roads are managed by Ada County Highway District, not the city, which adds coordination challenges.

üíº Wages vs. Cost of Living

Boise‚Äôs job market is generally healthy‚Äîbut local wages haven‚Äôt risen as fast as housing costs.

Result:

Many residents rely on remote work or dual incomes

Employers struggle to recruit for essential jobs (teachers, nurses, city staff, service workers)

This gap affects economic diversity and long-term stability.

üå≤ Environmental Pressures

Boise‚Äôs natural setting is a strength‚Äîbut also a vulnerability.

Challenges include:

Wildfire smoke affecting air quality in late summer

Water conservation as population grows

Protecting foothills, river corridors, and open space from overuse

Climate impacts are now part of routine city planning.

üèòÔ∏è Neighborhood Change & Identity

Rapid growth has changed the feel of some neighborhoods.

Tensions often center on:

Density vs. preservation

Infill development in established areas

Who Boise is ‚Äúfor‚Äù as it grows

This shows up frequently at City Council meetings and public hearings.

üè´ Public Services & Capacity

As population rises, so does demand for:

Schools

Parks and recreation

Police, fire, and emergency services

The challenge is scaling services without overburdening taxpayers.

üß≠ Civic Trust & Engagement

Boise has high civic participation, but growth has made decision-making more complex.

Issues include:

Public frustration with development processes

Misinformation around zoning and planning

Ensuring new residents engage with local civic norms

Keeping trust high requires transparency and outreach.

üìå In one sentence

Boise‚Äôs core challenge is managing rapid growth in a way that preserves affordability, livability, and community identity‚Äîwithout stalling progress.

If you want, I can break this down by:

Housing policy debates

Transportation plans

Environmental risks

What city leaders are prioritizing next

How residents can influence decisions

Just tell me what angle you want to explore.

results.queryText: What is Boise doing about affordable housing?
results.responseText:
Boise is actively working on affordable housing from several angles, combining direct investment, policy changes, partnerships, and support programs to try to address high rents and housing cost burdens. Here‚Äôs what the city (and partners) is doing:

üèóÔ∏è 1. Funding & Direct City Investment

The City of Boise has created and expanded dedicated affordable housing funds to support construction and preservation:

üí∞ Housing Investment Program
Boise‚Äôs Housing Investment Program supports building and preserving affordable housing units by partnering with developers and using city land or funding to make projects financially feasible. 
City of Boise

üíµ Surplus & budget allocations
In late 2025, the city council approved allocating $6.7 million from a budget surplus specifically for affordable housing development and preservation, expanding local investment beyond federal or state grants. 
BoiseDev
+1

Long-term funding strategy
City strategic priorities have also included allocating federal recovery dollars (ARPA) and other funding toward affordable housing goals. 
City of Boise

üè† 2. New Affordable Housing Projects

Boise is participating in ‚Äî or helping project partner funding for ‚Äî several new developments:

Wilson Station Apartments

Opened with 102 affordable units targeted to families earning below 80% of area median income. 
Idaho News 6 Boise Twin Falls (KIVI)

Dorado Station (West Boise)

Groundbreaking for a 212-unit affordable development that will include units restricted at 50‚Äì80% of area median income and homes set aside for people exiting homelessness. 
Idaho Business Review

Other supported projects

Smaller affordable homes are being developed through the city‚Äôs Affordable Housing Showcase and other incentive programs. 
City of Boise

Across these and related efforts, Boise (with partners) has helped result in hundreds of affordable units opening or planned since 2022. 
Idaho Business Review

üè¢ 3. Partnerships & Housing Authorities

The Boise City-Ada County Housing Authority (BCACHA) administers federal housing programs that help residents afford housing:

Section 8 / Housing Choice Vouchers assist families by subsidizing rent based on income. 
BCACHA Website 2023

Public housing and supportive housing programs provide stable homes for vulnerable populations. 
BCACHA Website 2023

These operate alongside city efforts, filling gaps and providing direct rental support.

üìÉ 4. Planning & Policy Tools

Boise has included affordable housing in planning and zoning:

Updated zoning to allow more housing types

In 2023, Boise rewrote its zoning code to allow duplexes and cottage court homes on most residential land ‚Äî a move intended to expand ‚Äúmissing middle‚Äù housing options and increase overall supply. 
Wikipedia

Annual Action Plans & consolidated planning

The city‚Äôs consolidated and annual action plans explicitly focus resources on increasing housing options for extremely low- to moderate-income households and addressing community development needs. 
City of Boise

Pilot programs & innovative approaches

Boise partnered with nonprofits like LEAP Housing on pilot initiatives that explore land-use innovations such as long-term tiny homes or RV housing strategies to help fill gaps for people priced out of traditional housing. 
Boise State University

üß† 5. Supportive Services & Eviction Prevention

Local campaigns coordinated with nonprofits (e.g., Jesse Tree, CATCH) have helped prevent evictions, provide rental navigation, and offer rapid rehousing for families facing homelessness. 
BoiseDev

These programs help keep people housed while longer-term housing production catches up.

üìå Summary: How Boise Is Addressing Affordable Housing

Boise‚Äôs approach includes:

Funding dedicated programs to build and preserve affordable units

Public‚Äìprivate partnerships to develop affordable multi-family housing

Federal housing subsidies (Section 8 vouchers, public housing) through local housing authorities

Zoning and policy changes to encourage diverse housing types

Supportive services and eviction prevention

Despite these efforts, demand still outpaces supply ‚Äî so the strategy is a mix of building more homes, supporting renters financially, and planning for long-term supply increases.

If you‚Äôd like, I can share how to apply for affordable housing assistance in Boise (vouchers, public housing, wait lists, etc.) and where to start.

results.queryText: What is Boise doing about homelessness?
results.responseText:
Boise is addressing homelessness through a mix of housing-focused programs, services, partnerships, and policy approaches rather than relying solely on enforcement. The issue remains complex (with hundreds of people experiencing homelessness in Ada County on any given night), but local leaders and community partners are working on several fronts. 
City of Boise
+1

üß± 1. Housing-First & Permanent Supportive Housing

Boise supports Housing First-style efforts, which prioritize getting people into stable housing as quickly as possible and then providing support services (case management, health care access, counseling, etc.). Programs like New Path Community Housing are examples of this approach, with evaluation showing positive outcomes in stability and reduced emergency service use. 
Boise State University
+1

üè† 2. Rehousing & Rapid Rehousing for Families

The City and housing partners (including CATCH, Jesse Tree, and the Boise City-Ada County Housing Authority) run campaigns to help families and individuals move into permanent housing with rental assistance and support:

Rental assistance helps households stay housed or get rehoused quickly.

Rapid rehousing programs reduced wait times for people moving into housing from roughly 305 days to about 206 days recently.

In a recent quarter, 17 families were housed with Section 8 vouchers and navigation help, and 23 families were rapidly rehoused.

Eviction prevention services supported families at risk of homelessness. 
BoiseDev

These efforts focus on practical pathways out of homelessness instead of episodic shelter stays.

üõ†Ô∏è 3. Coordinated Support & Resources

Boise maintains a housing crisis hotline (1-208-336-HOME) and connects people to services through partnerships like Our Path Home, which coordinates shelter, outreach, and housing resources throughout the community. 
Boise Homeless Coalition

Partner organizations and nonprofits also provide support such as:

Emergency shelter and food

Case management

Addictions recovery programs

Veteran services
(e.g., Boise Rescue Mission Ministries and others) 
Boise Rescue Mission Ministries

üìä 4. Shelters & Day Services

While Boise doesn‚Äôt criminalize homelessness, it ensures shelter beds, transitional housing, and outreach. Nonprofits and coalitions operate emergency shelters, women‚Äôs and children‚Äôs shelters, and transitional housing to help people exit homelessness. 
Boise Rescue Mission Ministries

üìú 5. Policy Stance ‚Äî Shelter & Resources First

City leaders emphasize avoiding criminalization of homelessness and focus on offering housing and support resources first. After court decisions around ‚Äúanti-camping‚Äù laws, Boise‚Äôs approach has been to link enforcement discretion with outreach and housing resources, rather than penalizing people for sleeping outdoors without options. 
Streetlight News

Mayor Lauren McLean has spoken publicly about continuing investments in permanent supportive housing and resisting enforcement-only strategies that don‚Äôt address underlying needs. 
Wikipedia

üìâ 6. Data & Trends

Recent Point-in-Time counts show fluctuations in the number of people experiencing homelessness; efforts aim not just to count but to improve services and reduce long-term housing instability. 
City of Boise
+1

Homelessness and housing instability in Boise are closely tied to regional housing affordability challenges, so many strategies focus on both prevention and rehousing, not just crisis response. 
Boise Homeless Coalition

üß† Summary: Boise‚Äôs Multi-Pronged Approach

Boise‚Äôs main strategies include:

Housing-first and permanent supportive housing programs

Rapid re-housing and eviction prevention

Coordinated crisis navigation and support services

Partnerships with nonprofits and housing authorities

Focus on resources and outreach instead of criminalization

If you want, I can share specific places in Boise where people experiencing homelessness can access shelter, meals, and services (with addresses and hours).

results.queryText: What is Boise doing about traffic congestion?
results.responseText:
Boise and its regional partners are actively planning and building solutions to address traffic congestion, recognizing that growth in the Treasure Valley has strained the existing road network. Traffic isn‚Äôt something one agency can solve alone ‚Äî transportation planning and improvements involve multiple organizations working together. 
City of Boise
+1

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening right now:

üöç 1. Expanding & Improving Public Transit

Valley Regional Transit is planning and upgrading transit services with the goal of helping more people travel without cars ‚Äî a key congestion strategy. Its Transit Development and Operations Plan (TDOP) guides expansions of service, capital projects, and improvements over the next several years. 
Valley Regional Transit

Other transit improvements include:

Upgraded bus stops and intersections (e.g., State & 18th bus stop rollouts). 
State Street Corridor

Planning for better service corridors like State Street with improved amenities and lane upgrades to make bus travel smoother. 
State Street Corridor

Increasing transit ridership helps reduce the number of cars on the road, especially during peak travel times.

üõ£Ô∏è 2. Roadway & Highway Projects

The Idaho Transportation Department (ITD) is investing in highway and major corridor improvements around Boise to reduce bottlenecks and improve flow. Projects include:

Studies and upgrades on I-84 and other busy corridors to improve mobility and capacity. 
Idaho Transportation Department

Design and planning phases for intersections, drainage and capacity enhancements on corridors like US-20/US-26 (Chinden) and SH-55 to straighten and expand where feasible. 
Idaho Transportation Department

These projects aim to keep traffic moving more reliably as population and vehicle counts grow.

üö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 3. Local & Neighborhood Transportation Planning

Transportation planning isn‚Äôt just highways ‚Äî local and neighborhood traffic matters too:

Ada County Highway District (ACHD) conducts neighborhood transportation planning and updates (like the Northwest Boise Transportation Plan) to identify where roads, bike/ped facilities, crossings and transit access can be improved. 
ACHD Engage

ACHD and partners also focus on ‚Äútraffic demand management‚Äù tools like carpooling, biking, and walking campaigns through programs like Commuteride, which give commuters alternatives and data to reduce drive-alone trips. 
ACHD Commuteride

Better local planning helps reduce congestion on neighborhood streets and improves connectivity without always adding lanes.

üó∫Ô∏è 4. Regional Coordination & Long-Range Plans

Traffic in Boise is part of a regional system, so local and countywide planning is critical:

The Transportation Action Plan (adopted by Ada County with input from cities and transportation agencies) aims to coordinate land use with transportation and better prioritize projects across jurisdictions. 
Ada County Idaho

Long-range planning through COMPASS (the regional planning organization) also sets priorities for transportation investment and helps secure funding for projects that reduce congestion.

üß† Why This Matters

Traffic congestion isn‚Äôt fixed overnight ‚Äî it‚Äôs a combination of transit improvements, roadway upgrades, better planning, and behavioral change (like using transit or carpooling). The ongoing projects and plans show Boise and partners are trying to reduce congestion systematically rather than simply widen roads. 
City of Boise

üìå Summary of Key Actions

Transit expansion and upgrades via Valley Regional Transit. 
Valley Regional Transit

Highway capacity and safety projects by ITD. 
Idaho Transportation Department

Neighborhood and corridor planning by ACHD. 
ACHD Engage

Regional planning coordination to align transportation and land use. 
Ada County Idaho

results.queryText: What is the Ada County Highway District?
results.responseText:
The Ada County Highway District (ACHD) is the independent local agency responsible for building, maintaining, and operating most public roads in Ada County‚Äîincluding the majority of streets in Boise.

üö¶ What ACHD Does

ACHD‚Äôs job is everything related to local roadway infrastructure, including:

Road construction & maintenance (potholes, resurfacing)

Traffic signals & signage

Snow plowing & street sweeping

Sidewalks, bike lanes, and crossings

Street lighting (on ACHD-managed roads)

Traffic studies & safety improvements

Development review (how new projects connect to streets)

If it‚Äôs a local street or arterial, ACHD likely runs it.

üó∫Ô∏è What ACHD Does Not Control

Interstates and state highways (like I-84, SH-21, SH-55) ‚Üí handled by the Idaho Transportation Department

City policy decisions (zoning, land use, housing) ‚Üí handled by Boise City government

This split is why traffic issues often involve multiple agencies.

üßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è How ACHD Is Governed

ACHD is run by a five-member Board of Commissioners

Commissioners are elected by district

It is independent of Boise City Hall (the mayor and city council do not control ACHD)

This structure is unique to Ada County in Idaho.

üèôÔ∏è Why ACHD Matters to Boise Residents

Complaints about potholes, traffic lights, speeding, crosswalks, or striping usually go to ACHD‚Äînot the city.

Many big congestion debates (State Street, Eagle Road, Chinden Blvd) are ACHD-led projects.

Boise can advocate, but ACHD decides timelines and designs for roads.

üìû How to Contact ACHD

Website: achdidaho.org

Main phone: (208) 387-6100

Report issues: ‚ÄúACHD Connect‚Äù (online request system)

In one sentence

ACHD is the agency that actually runs most of the roads in Boise and Ada County‚Äîeven though it‚Äôs separate from city government.

Figure out whether ACHD or the City handles a specific street

Report a road or traffic problem

results.queryText: How do I run for Boise City Council?
results.responseText:
To run for Boise City Council, you'll need to meet the qualifications and follow these steps:
Meet the Requirements: Be a registered voter in your district and meet the qualifications of the office.
Gather Documents: You'll need to complete a Declaration of Candidacy with a $40 filing fee or submit a Petition for Candidacy.
Submit Your Application: File your documents with the Ada County Elections Office, which partners with the City of Boise to ensure an open and fair election process.
Campaign Finance Reporting: As a candidate, you'll need to disclose financial information about your campaign as part of Idaho's Sunshine Law.
The next filing period for Boise City Council will likely be in August 2027, but it's best to check with the City of Boise Clerk's Office or Ada County Elections for the most up-to-date information

results.queryText: What is Boise doing about affordable housing?
results.responseText:
Boise is taking significant steps to address its affordable housing crisis. The city has been awarded $6.6 million from the U.S. Treasury's Social Impact Partnerships to Pay for Results Act (SIPPRA) program to support housing initiatives, aiming to build and sustain 250 new homes for individuals transitioning out of homelessness 
www.cityofboise.org
.
Key Initiatives:
Housing Incentives Program: Offers financial incentives for developers to create rental housing affordable to individuals and families earning at or below 80% Area Median Income.
Affordable Housing Showcase: Highlights current affordable housing projects, such as The Franklin and Denton apartments.
Fee Deferral for Affordable Housing: Provides fee exemptions and deferrals for affordable housing development.
Housing Land Trust: Leverages city-owned property to create affordable housing.
The city has also adopted a modern zoning code, streamlined entitlement and permitting processes, and invested over $50 million in local and federal funds to support affordable housing projects

Housing First: Boise has adopted the Housing First model, which prioritizes providing permanent housing to individuals and families as quickly as possible, followed by supportive services.

results.queryText: What is the Ada County Highway District?
results.responseText:
The Ada County Highway District (ACHD) is responsible for the construction, maintenance, and supervision of streets and roads in Ada County, Idaho, excluding state and federal highways. Established in 1971, ACHD provides planning, design, construction, reconstruction, maintenance, and traffic supervision for urban streets, rural roadways, and bridges

.
Key Responsibilities:
Road Maintenance: Ensuring roads are safe and well-maintained
Traffic Management: Managing traffic flow and safety
Infrastructure Development: Planning and constructing new roads and bridges
Community Engagement: Working with local communities to prioritize projects
ACHD is governed by a five-member Commission, elected to represent sub-districts within Ada County. The district works closely with local agencies, including the City of Boise and Idaho Transportation Department, to address transportation needs
